PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis, performed in February 2024, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Arctic Cold, LLC. facility located in Santa Maria, California. The mitigation measures include training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures. The Arctic Cold, LLC. management is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next 2.5 years or sooner as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Arctic Cold, LLC. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility. 

Arctic Cold, LLC. senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Arctic Cold, LLC. safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration system are administered by the Plant Manager with assistance from the Chief Engineer, who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Arctic Cold, LLC. facility is located at 1780 E. Betteravia Rd. Suite 102 in Santa Maria, California, which is approximately 1.1 miles east of US Route 101. Currently, the area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light industrial. The facility was constructed 2024 and will begin operations in April of the same year. 

The primary business of Arctic Cold, LLC. is to provide cooling and cold storage of various food products. To conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 50,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance. The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for the cold storage of food products. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the followin

g risk management regulations:

EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP);
OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and
California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). 

Administrative Measures:

The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:

IIAR 6, "Standard for inspection, testing,, and maintenance of safe closed-circuit ammonia refrigeration systems"

IIAR 7, "Developing operating procedures for close-circuit ammonia mechanical refrigeration systems.

The Arctic Cold, LLC. ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the Arctic Cold, LLC. facility operates in accordance with the Process Safety Management (PSM), Risk Management Program (RMP), and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program. It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits. Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.

Engineering Measures:

Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: emergency shutdown switches that kill power to the engine room equipment (located outside the Engine Room door), an emergency pressure control system to relieve pressure from a high pressure suction line to a lower pressure suction line, relief valves on all pressure vessels, continuous ventilation (controlled by a thermostat), and emergency ventilation in the Engine Room to prevent explosions. The facility has also installed ammonia sensors at strategi

c locations throughout the facility.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The refrigeration system at Arctic Cold, LLC. is of new construction at the time the PSM / RMP / CalARP documentation was submitted (April 2024). System start-up is scheduled for mid-April 2024. Therefore, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds, or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Arctic Cold, LLC. facility has an emergency action plan in effect. The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM / RMP / CalARP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.


The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP and CalARP regulations.

Arctic Cold, LLC. personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system. If an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, and the supervisor. The supervisor will contact the designated personnel to evaluate and ascertain the significance of the leak.
